A moot hall was a room for this purpose in a medieval building, but Wallace was a guerilla fighter, so could this meeting place have been his moot ha If this was so, perhaps Yellow Craig was a meeting place, where Wallace and his followers once met to discuss strategy. Could the idea of the letter to Luumlbeck have been decided here, as they cast their eyes across the sea from the vantage of the rock Itrsquos an interesting idea, but of course therersquos no historical evidence for it. Yet most of what actually happened in those times has no historical evidence.I couldnrsquot find the hole or hollow, as nature has claimed the slope and thick vegetation meant I was kept away from the recesses hidden behind. Perhaps winter would have been a better time to search.But I was not disappointed. I sat on the summit and my instinct told me there was a mystery here that remains untold. A scant and seemingly forgotten oral tradition is not much to go on. But often an ancient half-whispered tradition has grown from a seed of truth.There is a similar East Lothian connection to Wallace in the Garleton Hills. I have written of the Wallace Cave there and the traditions associated with it. There is enough connection to our national hero in East Lothian to say our landscape can also claim connection to him.I will search deeper for references to Wallacersquos Mutton Hole at Yellow Craig andmy findings to this pagemy search proves fruitful. But regardless of the results of this search, for me Yellow Craig will always be a place of magic contemplation and imaginative possibilities.

title: worlds-oldest-golf-scorecard-from-musselburgh-up-for-auction
story: Estimated at pound,-,, the card, which has been framed and mounted, dates from December , .It shows that a Mr Cundell played the five holes within the Musselburgh race track twice, a total of  holes in  strokes. Charmingly, the golfer provided his own commentary in a handwritten note at the bottom of the card: ldquoDreadful storm of wind and rain ndash atmosphere quite yellow ndash just like the lurid regions of Pandemonium.Mr Cundell is almost certainly James Cundell, who was closely involved with the Thistle Golf Club since its founding in  and who published one of the first ever rule books of golf in .Kevin McGimpsey, Bonhamsrsquo golfing memorabilia consultant, said: ldquoThis original scorecard is in remarkable condition considering its age and the atrocious weather conditions at the time Mr Cundell played his round.ldquoIt has an excellent provenance, having once belonged to the well-known golfer Sir Henry Cotton, who kept it in his renowned Black Tin Box with other rare examples of historical golfing memorabilia.ldquoThe scorecard predates the oldest cards owned by the international golf museums.The scorecard will be auctioned at Bonhamsrsquo next sporting sale at its  Queen Street saleroom on Wednesday, which will present Part II of The Pierre Horwitz Collection of golfing memorabilia. This covers the period from the early part of the th century to the s and concentrates especially on the manufacture of clubs and balls and rare patented designs of both.Other highlights include: a white painted feather golf ball, handmade in about  by Allan Robertson, one of the most gted of the early professional golfers and a long nosed scared neck putter from about - made by Robert Forgan. The Pierre Horwitz collection Part I made a total of pound, last October.Documentary evidence proves that golf was played on Musselburgh Links as early as  although Mary, Queen of Scots reputedly played there in .

title: 110000-boost-for-musselburgh-charitys-work
story: The funding to the Bridges Centre, awarded over three years, will go towards the salary costs of a full-time personal development worker to deliver a programme of inidual and small group support to --year-olds.This will help young people develop their skills and aspirations for the future as the service seeks to build their emotional resilience and help them create positive relationships, enabling them to achieve their full potential.The grant, which was allocated through Children in Needrsquos Main Grants Programme, is its first funding allocation of the year, with additional cash-aid being distributed to projects across the UK throughout .Jim Boyle, chief executive of the Bridges Project, which is based on Musselburghrsquos Bogpark Road, said: ldquoWersquove been receiving funding from BBC Children in Need now for the last  years and, in that time, have been able to make a dference to hundreds of young peoplersquos lives.ldquoWersquore delighted that wersquoll be able to continue this for another three years in collaboration with our partners in education, social work, health and the voluntary sector.Florence Burke, national head of Scotland at BBC Children in Need, said: ldquoWe are delighted to fund the work of the Bridges Project and look forward to seeing the dference that this grant will make to children and young people across the region.Simon Antrobus, BBC Children in Needrsquos chief executive, added: ldquoAs always, thanks must go to our generous supporters and fundraisers. We are only able to make these much-needed awards because of them.In East Lothian and Midlothian, BBC Children in Need is currently funding nine projects to a value of pound,.Across Scotland, it has more than pound. million invested in projects making a positive dference to the lives of disadvantaged young people.For information on how to apply for funding, visit bbc pudsey grants

title: young-county-ballet-prodigy-gets-tuition-from-dance-star
story: Maisie Belle Black was trained for the day in Edinburgh by Danish dancer, choreographer and director Peter Schaufuss.The -year-old started learning at Dunbar School of Dance at the age of three and now trains with Scottish Ballet and the Edinburgh Ballet.She said: ldquoI love dancing. It gives me the freedom to express myself and I particularly enjoy the technical precision of ballet.ldquoI currently train several times a week but am always looking for more opportunities to dance and perform.Maisie, a student at Mary Erskine School, has already competed in many competitions including the Dance World Cup and Thatrsquos Showbiz.She had attended workshops at Edinburgh Festival Ballet School last year and jumped at the chance to work with the world-famous ballet dancer.She added: ldquoIrsquod heard a lot about Peter Schaufuss and his son Luke before as they are both very well-known.ldquoGetting to work with Peter was an amazing opportunity and I really enjoyed it.The famous dancer Schaufuss has performed and directed all over the world with leading companies including Kirov Ballet, Paris Opera Ballet, Royal Ballet and New York City Ballet, as well as founding The English National Ballet School.He said: ldquoThe masterclass presents an opportunity for Scottish dancers to spend a day learning from those that have been at the highest level of the dance profession.ldquoItrsquos an opportunity for students to be taught by some of the leading figures from the dance world and to learn what it takes to be a professional dancer.The class itself was designed by Schaufuss, who has plans to have a full-time school up and running from September based at St Stephenrsquos Church in Stockbridge, Edinburgh.Maisie added: ldquoMy ultimate dream is to be a professional dancer and perform every day.

title: magazine-aims-to-entice-new-haddington-residents-into-town-centre
story: Businesses in the town centre have joined forces to work on a magazine entitled lsquoMy Haddingtonrsquo.Moira Graham, of Haddington Business Community Partnership , said: ldquoWe are proposing to put together a one-off glossy magazine. We are going to run , copies aimed at the new housing.ldquoWith lots of local community members, our community groups are going to write their own editorials and tell us a little about what happens in Haddington.Members of HBCP, including award-winning Blooming Haddington, Friends of the River Tyne and ious sports groups, have been asked to contribute to the magazine, which will be A size.Mrs Graham added: ldquoAll the groups are going to have a wee say in it.ldquoA lot of people know what a great place Haddington is to live and work.ldquoWe are aiming to publish in the summer.Work is already under way to build more than  new homes at Letham Mains, between Haddingtonrsquos West Road and Pencaitland Road.Similarly, more than  new homes are being built at Dovecot, to the south of Pencaitland Road.Business representatives have repeatedly stressed the importance of attracting new residents into the centre to boost the local economy.The proposed magazine was highlighted at Haddingtonrsquos community council meeting and received the backing of long-standing chairwoman Jan Wilson.She described Haddington as ldquoa beautul town, steeped in history.Mrs Wilson said: ldquoLet us hope it will bring people into the town to use the town centre.ldquoIf this magazine can bring people together and make them aware of the things going on in the town it has to be a good thing.

title: disruption-expected-during-four-months-of-pipeline-work-near-morham
story: Five kilometres of pipeline will run from Cockles Brae, south of Haddington, to the Morham crossroads.The new pipe will, says Scottish Water, improve the reliability and resilience of the water supply network for customers in the local area and the wider network.The pipe will run through fields, a burn and across roads, replacing an old nine-inch steel pipe which has come to the end of its le.The work sees Scottish Water Alliance partner Caledonia Water Alliance in stripping soil from the route before cutting a trench for the new pipeline.During the work, which is expected to take about four months, there will be some short periods of local road closures and residents in these areas will be kept informed, says Scottish Water.Scottish Waterrsquos Scott Fraser said: ldquoThis new pipeline will ensure that customers can continue to enjoy a reliable supply of clear, fresh drinking water.

title: rocket-firm-hopes-to-test-engines-at-former-power-station-site
story: Skyrora has revealed it has identied part of the old Cockenzie Power Station site as a location for its test site.The company, which describes itself as a launch vehicle development company with aims to cater for the growing demand to send small satellites into space, is expected to apply for planning permission from East Lothian Council within the next few months.It held a public consultation on its proposals at the Port Seton Centre today .The Courier revealed last August that Skyrora were looking at East Lothian sites, with the former power station one of the possibilities it was considering to test its rocket engines.Skyrora said that the engine testing would not involve the launching of rockets from the site but would require fuel to be stored on-site to fire up the engines.The UK Space Agency announced that it was investing millions of pounds in a site in Sutherland as the new home of the UKrsquos first spaceport for launching rockets.Skyrora said it was looking for an engine test site within an hour of its Edinburgh offices to give it a local base.It said it had identied part of the former power station site, which was bought by East Lothian Council last year, for its tests.The area being put forward for the site is part of the old coal store.Skyrora said: ldquoThe site will be protected, and special measures will be undertaken to control down the noise impacts to acceptable levels and minimal-period test events.Last year it was revealed that Glasgow produced more space satellites than any other city outside of the USA.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoWe have been in discussions with Skyrora about the possibility of a temporary lease of land for activities based around engine testing.ldquoA planning application would need to be submitted by Skyrora and considered in due course.

title: stray-dog-driven-400-miles-to-coatbridge-after-being-found-on-m25
story: The black female lurcher was discovered on the M in Uxbridge, West London, before being picked up and driven to the North Lanarkshire town.She was handed into a police station and officers contacted the Scottish SPCA, who have taken her into their care.Peter Fleming, manager of the Scottish SPCArsquos Lanarkshire centre, said: ldquoWe were notied by Police Scotland of the dog who had been handed into the police station in Coatbridge.ldquoWe were very surprised to hear where she came from.ldquoShe is a very friendly girl and is in good health, the staff have named her Paloma.ldquoThe member of the public found Paloma straying on the M in Uxbridge, West London, and put her in his vehicle and travelled the long distance to Coatbridge.Anyone who recognises the dog has been asked to contact the charity.

title: fees-propping-up-school-music-tuition-say-councils
story: Cosla, the umbrella body for local authorities, said wider budget cuts meant charges were vital to keeping the service going.The statement came in a briefing for MSPs on the eve of a debate in the Scottish Parliament on rising charges for instrumental music tuition.The number of councils charging for instrumental music has risen from  to  since  , with fees increasing from pound to pound. The maximum charge is now pound.In January, Holyroodrsquos education committee recommended music tuition should be free to all after an inquiry into the issue.Read more:Musical flashmob campaigns against free school tuition cutsIts report said: ldquoThe ... committee respects the democratic right of local authorities to take decisions about local expenditure and acknowledges the financial choices they face.ldquoHowever, the committee believes in principle that music tuition should be provided free of charge in every local authority.Cosla said the report ldquomakes no recommendation on how this would be funded.The briefing said: ldquoGiven that charges help to fund provision, without the ability to charge it is likely that provision would be reduced.Read more:Anger as the number of music teachers in Scots primary schools drops by %ldquoEvery local authority which charges for instrumental music tuition offers concessions and there are no charges for pupils in receipt of free school meals or those pupils studying for examinations.ldquoNo local authority introducing charges for any service takes the decision lightly, but there needs to be a recognition of the financial constraints local authorities are working with and they are having to make extremely dficult decision as a result of continued cuts to their core budgets.Cosla said since   local government budgets had decreased signicantly, with core funding down by pound. billion in real terms.Some , pupils received instrumental music lessons in  .

title: man-gets-scotlands-oldest-hydro-electric-pump-working-after-100-years
story: While across the country new hydropower schemes are helping to feed the revolution in renewables and clean energy, in a hut beside a babbling burn on an estate near Dundee, the forerunner of them all is efficiently and calmly still going about its business.Just as the rest of us might use the garden hut to store the family bikes, a few tools, the lawnmower and maybe mouldy camping gear, Duncan Stewart throws open the door to his workshop to reveal Scotlandrsquos oldest working hydropower Turgo water turbine.Read more:Scottish beauty spot used in James Bond film threatened by major hydro electricity projectInstalled in  ndash just weeks after the first hp Turgo was fitted at Invergeldie Lodge, near Crieff ndash Mr Stewartrsquos personal kW hydropower system is not only generating energy to heat and provide hot water for his five-bedroom house in Burnside of Duntrune, therersquos even enough left over for him to sell on to the National Grid.As a result, Mr Stewart and his we Pat not only live virtually energy bill-free thanks to the turbine, but they also derive some tax-free income from it.ldquoIt is remarkable to think that something installed  years ago is working so well, said Mr Stewart, . ldquoAs a result of it, most of our heating is free, it heats our water and powers a log splitter that provides me with logs for my wood-burning stove that keeps us warm in winter. Itrsquos not just saving us money, itrsquos making money too.Duncan Stewart with the hydropower turbine, which is generating energy after being installed in .The engineering treasure draws its water from the nearby Fithie Burn, which was dammed by workmen using shovels, horses and carts in the months after the First World War.However, water-driven power at the site dates back even earlier ndash to more than  years ago, when there was a mill with a water wheel in the area.The ft high, ft long turbine was originally installed in a workshop serving Duntrune Estate, powering a large circular saw and sending electricity to Duntrune House, nearby Craighill House and Burnside House, the former estate managerrsquos home.When the Stewarts moved to Burnside House almost  years ago, the turbine was still providing electricity to the property ndash albeit via a quickly dismantled hazardous DC connection ndash alongside a mains connection.However, it eventually ground to a halt and was mothballed while the couple opted for more ldquomodern mains supply electricity and an oil-fired range cooker and boiler.It lay rusting until Mr Stewart met television presenter and engineer Lieutenant-Colonel Dick Strawbridge at an event and happened to mention the turbine lurking in his shed.ldquoHe said, lsquoget it fixed, it could be your pensionrsquo, recalled Mr Stewart.Read more:Energy giant plans hefty investment in windfarms and car chargers in ScotlandInspired, he dusted grime from the rusty turbinersquos nameplate and discovered it was a Turgo turbine, manufactured by Cumbria-based Gilbert Gilkes  Gordon Ltd. Papers related to its commission and invoices confirmed it had been installed in  ndash the same year the revolutionary turbine was designed by Eric Crewdson, who had outlined its features while serving in the trenches of the war.Crewdson conceived the idea of a side-entry impulse turbine capable of running at twice the speed of a Pelton water-wheel turbine, with a higher efficiency across a broad flow range.Within months of ing from the war, his concept had been developed and the first Turgo turbine installed at a property in Crieff.However, it is no longer operational ndash making the Stewartsrsquo refurbished and repainted turbine the oldest operational example version of its type in Scotland.The refurbishment was carried out by the original manufacturers, while Mr Stewart set about removing a build-up of silt from the burn.He added: ldquoThe turbinersquos governor alone, which controls the flow of water and is a beautul piece of engineering, must have weighed half a tonne ndash the new one only weighs around half a pound. Now it all works beautully.The savings ndash and earnings ndash have been signicant. Hydropower is used to heat the propertyrsquos water and radiators, enabling the Stewarts to reduce oil consumption, as well as powering the log splitter to feed the stove. ldquoI now use about , to , litres of oil when a house this size would normally require , litres, Mr Stewart added, ldquowhile I get paid for whatever energy is generated regardless of how much actually goes to the Grid.ldquoItrsquos now part of our le.The only downside, he adds, isa dry spell hits and the local farmers opt to use additional local water to irrigate their crops, leaving an insufficient flow to power the system.Hydropower has recently surged in popularity, with dozens of community-run schemes now either in operation or in the planning stages.Hannah Smith, senior policy manager at Scottish Renewables, said: ldquoHydropower is one of Scotlandrsquos great unsung heroes, using our notorious wet weather to provide  per cent of Scotlandrsquos gross electricity demand while reducing the carbon emissions which cause climate change.ldquoMr and Mrs Stewartrsquos turbine is one of Scotlandrsquos oldest, and the fact it is still in service in its th year demonstrates how hydro delivers subsidy-free power long after support provided by government has ceased.She added that the Scottish Renewables Hydro Conference, in Perth on May , is set to explore further ways to ensure hydropower technologyrsquos role in the future energy landscape, particularly in wake of the closure of the Feed-in Tarf scheme earlier this month.

title: pressure-mounts-on-jeremy-corbyn-from-inside-and-outside-labour-to-back-peoples-vote-on-brexit
story: As four trade union chiefs urged the Labour leader to commit the party to a confirmatory vote, so too did the SNPrsquos Ian Blackford and the Liberal Democratsrsquo Vince Cable.The increasing pressure on Mr Corbyn came as a glimmer of hope emerged in the cross-party Brexit talks, now in their fth week.David Lidington, Theresa Mayrsquos de facto deputy, described the latest meeting as ldquopositive" and "productive".The Cabinet Office Minister admitted to being "encouraged" by a sense from both sides about the "need to inject greater urgency" into the talks. He said more meetings would take place later this week.Sue Hayman, the Shadow Environment Secretary, was equally upbeat, saying there had been a "really constructive discussion" as the two parties were "getting much more into the nuts and bolts of the detail".Earlier, Shami Chakrabarti, the Shadow Attorney General, said Labour colleagues involved in the talks had to tell the partys ruling National Executive Committee on Tuesday "whether there is any hope for a sensible Brexit" or the only means of breaking the deadlock was a second referendum or a general election.Thus far, Mr Corbyn has been reluctant to move further on backing another EU poll some colleagues believe it would be a betrayal of the  vote and would harm Labour in some of its key north of England strongholds.But four major union leaders are pressing the party leader to include a second referendum pledge in Labourrsquos Euro poll manesto: Unisonrsquos Dave Prentis the GMBrsquos Tim Roache and USDAWrsquos Paddy Lillis and the TSSA transport unionrsquos Manuel Cortes.The latter said: ldquoFrankly, itrsquos time for our party to act on the overwhelming wishes of its members and votes by pledging to support a confirmatory public vote on any Brexit deal.In a letter to the Labour leader, Mr Blackford warned him that he was ldquofacilitating a Brexit disaster.The Highland MP said: ldquoJeremy Corbyn must stop blocking a second EU referendum and start working with the SNP to prevent Brexit and the lasting harm it will cause.He claimed thatthe Labour leader refused to show leadership on the issue, his party would be just as culpable as the Tories for the damage to jobs, living standards, the economy and public services.In his own letter to Mr Corbyn, Sir Vince urges him to ldquopush for the inclusion of a confirmatory public referendum in your European manesto.Tom Brake, the Lib Demsrsquo Brexit spokesman, added: "It is long overdue that the Leader of the Labour Party backs his own party policy and helps make the final say a reality.Elsewhere, Michel Barnier, the EUrsquos chief Brexit negotiator, said in a speech in Belgium that it was six months since the UK and EU agreed a deal. "We need to fix Brexit quickly, he declared.

title: neil-mackay-five-key-issues-the-yes-movement-must-address-if-it-wants-to-win-well
story: The Yes movement, which in  was vibrant, optimistic and positive, has become typied by marching and shouting. Therersquos a sense that it has degenerated into a st century Grand Old Duke of York. People parade around towns waving Saltires, but to what avail  Whorsquos being convinced  Which minds are being changed :European election results can help Nicola Sturgeon in push for Scottish independenceEven worse than the gesture politics of pointless parades is the dominance of ugly voices among the grassroots. Itrsquos asthe tide went out after the first referendum ndash taking with it the upbeat, the persuasive, the intelligent, the charismatic ndash leaving behind the abusive, the vulgar, the reactionary, the dumb.Instead of the broad spectrum of informed voices and big ideas of , wersquore left with well-meaning marchers going nowhere, and internet trolls in their basements.Many of the problems stem from the vacuum left after defeat in  ndash the base wanted to keep on, but the SNP leadership chose slow, pragmatic, managerial politics. Whorsquod blame them  The SNP is a political party which wants to win office. It had to keep throwing red meat to the base with cries of ldquoindy is coming, while trying to maintain electoral appeal beyond independence voters.There are five key issues the Yes movement must look to ithopes to win independence well. The first is the tone of debate. Before the last referendum, many voters inherently distrustful of nationalism were brought over to Yes because it seemed open and embracing, it offered an alternative to failed Westminster. Progressives and centrists, and even some on the right, found a comfortable home as Yes voters. There was still a brittle, nasty online presence but it seemed of little intellectual importance.However, today, it appears asthis shrill minority is the dominant voice. The table seating needs readjustingtherersquos to be success. Put these petulant ldquoshouty people at the back of the room.This isnrsquot about silencing voices, they are free to say what they please, but those in leadership positions must speak up against this fringe which repels those considering a Yes vote. Stop following these people on social media, stop amplying their nasty messages ndash especiallyyoursquore in elected office.Which takes us to our second point ndash outreach. The Yes movement must once again start chasing voters and not talking to itself. Woo undecideds. Woo Unionists. Woo everyone. Self-congratulatory backslapping does nothing. Waving a Saltire in the face of Unionists wonrsquot win votes. Marching around a town wonrsquot change anyonersquos mind.Itrsquos not just that many in the base of whatrsquos left of the Yes movement arenrsquot attracting enough new voters to their side, some are wilfully deterring newcomers. The use of the derogatory term ldquoYoonto describe Unionists is guaranteed to offend and repel. Do some really believe insulting people and laughing at them will convert anyone  If MI wanted to cook up an intelligence operation to undermine Scottish independence they could do no better than many of the biggest online voices who claim to back Yes.A banner was unveiled outside the SNP conference at the weekend saying ldquoEngland get out of Scotland. We donrsquot need those who would try to make independence ugly. Scotland isnrsquot occupied. England isnrsquot an enemy. The banner was by a member of Scottish Resistance. Resisting who exactly  English paratroopers over Peebles  Get a le and get out of the way of people who really want to change this country for the better.:Scottish independence poll: One in five Scots back Nicola Sturgeons Indyref planItrsquos even worse when those not part of the lunatic fringe embarrass. Also at the SNP conference was Dave Thompson, former SNP MSP and chair of Voices for Scotland which is meant to be an ldquoinclusive" Yes campaign group. Mr Thompson used Gaelic and Scots to introduce himself to delegates and added: ldquoApologies to those who do not have the two proper languages of Scotland. Really  It may have been a joke, but is this what we want to hear from a party which says it welcomes EU residents Thirdly, the Yes movement needs to get real over dficult questions. Voters have been exhausted and terried by Brexit. The SNP grassroots may want to scrap the pound, but itrsquos not a policy thatrsquos going to win new Yes voters ndash it will only scare them. When it comes to independence, undecideds are now worried about trade deals with England and a possible hard border. Brexit has made independence more dficult as itrsquos raised more questions.No-one sane wants independence to pile on more ision after Brexit. Thatrsquos why the creation of Citizensrsquo Assemblies, to work out the future of Scotland, is a welcome move. Take these big frightening questions directly to the people and to experts and letrsquos hear the evidence and the truth. Momentous change needs rigorous analysis and adult honesty.Fourthly, independence is too big for the SNP alone ndash Scotland is not the SNPrsquos country, it is the peoplersquos, and Citizensrsquo Assemblies can help us work out what is in all our best interests when it comes to our constitutional future, rather than in the narrow interests of one party. It must be said over and over again that a Yes vote is not an SNP vote.I want to see Scotland independent but I want to know the full hard truths before I vote again ndash and I fervently do not want to see this country ided against itself.Perhaps, then, the fth issue is the hardest for many Yes voters to accept ndash that a mere win in any second referendum is not enough, maybe we need to set ourselves a  per cent margin before enacting change. It would be bold, it would ease fears among Unionists, it would show that the Yes movement cares about the country, not just itself, and many may find that appealing and attractive.Most importantly, do we want Scotland in the wake of a close win for independence ndash like a - margin ndash to go through the pain and hatred Britain has already gone through with Brexit  I want independence ndash but I do not want that.Neil Mackay is Scotlandrsquos Columnist of the Year.

title: margaret-taylor-the-glasgow-metro-plan-is-bold-ambitious-and-vital
story: Take Glasgow. Having once boasted an extensive tram system that connected all corners of the city and beyond to its bustling centre, it now relies on the only subway in the world never to have been extended, a bus network so inadequate that a quarter of its inhabitants must take at least two buses to get to work, and a rail network that, despite being the UKrsquos best outside London, remains disjointed and struggles on a daily basis to keep up with demand.Sure, several subway stations have been scrubbed up in recent years and the pound million revamp of Queen Street Station will bring a long-overdue injection of modernity to one of the cityrsquos main transport hubs, but itrsquos hardly the stuff of a thriving metropolis with pretensions of becoming a major player on the European scene. Plans unveiled by the Glasgow Connectivity Commission, a body founded two years ago by council leader Susan Aitken and chaired by transport expert Professor David Begg, could change all that, bringing benefits not just to the city but its inhabitants too.In a report published this week, the commission has unveiled bold plans for transforming Glasgow into an ldquoinclusive, thriving, liveable city within the next  years by, among other things, enclosing the section of the M that cuts a polluting tract through the city and creating a cycle-route network that connects the economic centre to the suburbs and surrounding areas that feed it. It is the proposal for a Glasgowthat could make the biggest dference overall, though, by bringing parts of the city that were cut off when the tram system was abandoned and rail network rationalised out of their imposed isolation.The plans for Glasgow itself would see abandoned rail routes such as the one that connected Maryhill to the West End via a stop at the Botanic Gardens reinstated, while a new line would create a much-needed link between Renfrew, Braehead, the Queen Elizabeth University Hospital and the city centre. A tunnel under the Clyde, meanwhile, would link the services operating out of Queen Street and Central stations to create a joined-up service stretching across the whole of the Central Belt while an extension to Glasgow Central would pave the way for the kind of high-speed services that would make it possible to travel between Glasgow and London in three hours or less.The plan for Glasgow Airport, which revives the idea of a rail link to Paisley Gilmour Street for a connection to Glasgow rather than one straight to the city centre itself, remains highly unsatisfactory for a city that craves a role on the global stage. Anyone who has made the frustratingly fractured journey from Luton Airport to Luton Airport Parkway then onto the centre of London could tell you that a city that has secured signicant job-creating investments from employers like Barclays but will always compete with the likes of Manchester and Birmingham for further deals should know it too. But with the report noting that connectivity ldquois the leblood of any socio-economic system and that transport networks ldquoinfluence a cityrsquos quality of le, shape its urban fabric and determine the type of economic activity it supports, the bulk of its recommendations are exciting.Too much of Glasgow and its surrounding areas remain cut off from the parts of the city where jobs are created and sustained, with the two-thirds of the population who live near a train station or own a car most likely to benefit from those evolving opportunities while the third that do not remain left behind. Indeed, it should come as no surprise that the report found the most deprived areas of the city are poorly served by the rail network while the richest parts are not. A new train line will never solve the multi-layered social problems our most abandoned communities have been left to deal with, particularly as some of those problems pre-date the advent of the connectivity our most advantaged ones enjoy. It can provide an opportunity to help narrow the worst socio-economic gaps, though.One of the biggest barriers to such potentially transformational projects will always be the cost and the Glasgow Connectivity Commission reckons it will take pound billion over  years to make its vision a reality. In a pothole-ridden city that canrsquot even keep its streets clean today that is going to be one hell of an ask. And, with major projects such as the Queensferry Crossing, Edinburgh tram line and Aberdeen Western Peripheral Route already demonstrating how hard ambitious budgets and timetables can be to stick to, a project that would dwarf all of them in terms of scope and scale will remain a daunting one.Yet with the project promising to enhance Glasgowrsquos economic fortunes to the benefit of all its citizens, it must be a price worth paying. As Professor Begg said, ldquowe need to raise Glasgowrsquos levels of ambitionsuch a transformation is to be achieved.Dare we be so bold  We canrsquot afford not to be.Read more: Plans for a Glasgownetwork and Central-Queen Street tunnel unveiled

title: israeli-firm-bids-to-buy-2bn-north-sea-oil-and-gas-portfolio
story: Reuters reported that Delek had confirmed in a regulatory filing in Tel Aviv that it was in talks to buy Chevronrsquos oil and gas fields in the UK North Sea as part of its international expansion plans.Delek did not provide financial details in the filing but said a deal could be completed this year.The company has already shown it is willing to invest big sums in the North Sea. It acquired Aberdeen-based Ithaca Energy in  in a deal that valued the firm at poundbn.Ithaca has expanded in the North Sea under Delekrsquos ownership. The company increased its exposure to the flagship Greater Stella development last year by acquiring stakes from Dyas UK and Petrofac in a deal worth up to around m.The sale of the Chevron portfolio would represent a signicant development in the shake up in the North Sea triggered by the crude price plunge from .Some majors have sold North Sea assets to raise funds to invest in what they see as more promising areas, including the shale fields of the US.Chevron has made a bn bid to acquire Anadarko, which has extensive holdings in the Permian shale basin in Texas and New Mexico.Earlier this month Americarsquos ConocoPhillips agreed to sell its North Sea portfolio to UK-based independent Chrysaor Energy for .bn.Delek describes itself as one of Israelrsquos biggest companies and a pioneer of exploration in the eastern Mediterranean, where it has made big finds with partners.The Central North Sea portfolio Chevron plans to offload features four operated fields east of Aberdeen, including Alba and Captain, and stakes in other assets. The grouprsquos UK production averaged , barrels oil equivalent per day in .Last month Premier Oil was reported to have linked up with US private equity firm Apollo Global Management to bid for the Chevron portfolio.

title: study-suggests-no-link-between-sugary-drinks-and-high-calorie-intake-in-children
story: A study, presented at the European Congress on Obesity in Glasgow, found no direct link between the consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages and higher overall energy consumption in four to -year-olds.There were also no signicant dferences between the body mass indexesof children who consumed sugary soft drinks and those who did not.:Why following a food blogger can lsquodamage your healthrsquoThe study suggests the sugar tax, which came into effect last year, ldquomight not be the most effective tactic to fight childhood obesity, the researchers said.The team, from the University of Nottingham, analysed data from a survey of around , UK children aged four to , between  and , including a four-day food diary.In total, % of the children drank at least one sugary soft drink during this period, but more than three-quartersof this group did not exceed their total recommended daily calorie intake.There were no signicant dferences in the BMIs of drinkers and non-drinkers, the authors said.Overall, % of the children consumed more than the recommended daily amount of added sugars, including that found in fruit juices and confectionery, the study also found.This figure was % among drinkers of sugar-sweetened beverages.ldquoHigh intake of added sugars was not directly correlated with high energy consumption, Ola Anabtawi, who led the research, said.ldquoTherefore, relying on a single-nutrient approach to tackling childhood obesity in the form of a soft drink tax might not be the most effective tactic.:Obese people with active commute could cut risk of early death, study suggestsShe added: ldquoOur findings indicate that drinking sugar-sweetened beverages is not a behaviour particular to children with a higher body weight.ldquoOn the contrary, framing sugar reduction in tackling obesity might reinforce negative stereotypes around lsquounhealthy dietingrsquo.ldquoInstead, policies should focus on those children whose consumption of sugar-sweetened drinks substantially increases their total added sugar intake in combination with other public health interventions.Commenting on the findings, Dr Katarina Kos, from the University of Exeter, warned the effects of sugar intake may only become apparent among children in later le.ldquoThe study should not be seen as reassurance that we can relax about sugar-sweetened drinks, but as the authors also say, it highlights the complexity of environment, she said.ldquoChildren do exercise less than they used to, thus need fewer calories and less energy, whatever the source.:Too many people waiting too long for treatment, says Health SecretaryMatt Lambert, nutritionist at World Cancer Research Fund, said: ldquoWhile consumption of sugary drinks was not shown to be a factor for weight gain in this particular study, this is typically because children who consume more sugary drinks eat less healthy foods as they are full from the lsquoempty caloriesrsquo of the sugar-sweetened drinks, which are usually devoid of essential nutrients.ldquoIt is clear that drinking sugary drinks is just one piece of the puzzle when it comes to weight gain.ldquoThe over-consumption of fast foods and other processed foods high in fat, starches or sugars, coupled with a sedentary lestyle are all other important factors, and a broad range of complementary policies will be needed to see a decline in childhood obesity rates.

title: theresa-may-mindful-of-public-mood-and-wants-to-wrap-up-cross-party-talks-next-week-one-way-or-the-other
story: Now into their fth week, the discussions have been ldquoserious and constructive, according to No , and yesterdayrsquos meeting appeared to be the most successful to date.David Lidington, Theresa Mays de facto deputy, described that meeting as "productive," saying he had been "encouraged" by a sense from both sides about the "need to inject greater urgency" into the talks.:Brexit extension: What happens next  Will Theresa May quit  Heres everything you need to knowLabourrsquos Sue Hayman, the Shadow Environment Secretary, was equally upbeat, saying there had been a "really constructive discussion" as the two parties were "getting much more into the nuts and bolts of the detail".Nonetheless, serious dferences still exist on a number of issues, not least that of a customs union, Labourrsquos official policy.Jeremy Hunt, the Foreign Secretary, warned that the Government risked losing Tory supportit agreed to a customs union plan.He told BBC Radio s Today programme: "If we were proposing, which I very much hope we dont, to sign up to the customs union, then there is a risk that you would lose more Conservative MPs than you would gain Labour MPs."If, on the other hand, it was something dferent, then the result could be dferent as well."A Cabinet colleague has told The Herald the cross-party talks are doomed as Jeremy Corbyn believes, politically, he has more to gain from them collapsing.However, others disagree, believingthe Labour leader agreed a compromise this would split the Tories and boost Nigel Faragersquos Brexit Party. Equally though, it would also split Labour as Mr Corbyn is unlikely to put any cross-party deal to a second referendum which most of Labourrsquos grassroots want.:Theresa May urged to put fight against climate change on war footing by cross-party politiciansThe Government has to raty WAB for the UK to leave the EU. Ministerial sources have said the legislation will have to be introduced after this weekrsquos English local elections ndash when the Tories are expecting to get a drubbing - and before the scheduled European elections on May  ndash when they are expected to get another drubbing.This means the likelihood is WAB will be introduced next week or the week after.Any deal with Labour would have to include a cast-iron guarantee that it would back WAB through all its parliamentary stages.Todayrsquos weekly Cabinet discussed Brexit and the state of play regarding the Con-Lab talks. Julian Lewis, the Chief Whip, updated colleagues on the passage of WAB.Theresa Mayrsquos spokesman declined to get into specics about the meeting but said: ldquoThere is an understanding on the need to make progress on delivering Brexit the way to leave the EU with a deal is via securing safe passage of the Withdrawal Agreement Bill[WAB]. What I am saying today will reflect the understanding that the Government needs to be making progress to deliver what the British people voted for.Askedthe Government had calculated how many parliamentary days it needed to get the legislation through, he explained how a great deal of work had already gone into preparing WAB but suggested no one could be precise about how many days the bill would take.However, the spokesman stressed there was a ldquofull understanding throughout Cabinet of the need to make progress as soon as possible and that the British public want Parliament to ldquoget on with it.One senior Whitehall source has made clear: ldquoThere is urgency and there is no point in continuingtalks are not in a productive state we donrsquot feel that is the case at the moment but obviously there can be no open-ended duration.Askedthe Government was hoping to wrap things up by the end of this week, he made clear no specic date was being set but again stressed the urgency to make progress as quickly as possible.More talks between the parties are due in the coming days but there is a firm recognition within Whitehall that after several weeks of talks the public wants things to be brought to a conclusion one way or another.

title: mackay-accused-of-being-in-full-retreat-on-new-currency
story: The Scottish Tories claimed the Finance Secretary was in ldquofull retreat after he emphasised the caveats attached to his partyrsquos new policy, rather than its merits.Mr Mackay also stressed the SNPrsquos proposals involving keeping the pound initially, and Holyrood would decidethere should be a change, subject to six stringent tests.He said: ldquoOur position is clear. Until a new currency can be safely and established in the interests of the whole economy, the currency of an independent Scotland should continue to be the pound sterling.ldquoIt will be for an independent Scottish Parliament when the time is right -there is that change - based on the right economic position for Scotland.:Iain Macwhirter: Therersquos no need for the SNP to take a pounding over currency issueDelegates to the SNPrsquos spring conference voted on Saturday by  to  to establish a new currency ldquoas soon as practicable, subject to six tests.The vote was a surprise defeat from Nicola Sturgeon and Mr Mackay, who had advocated a more gradual approach, with no new currency for at least a decade, in keeping with the SNPs Growth Commission.The policy sht offered the First Ministerrsquos unionist opponents, including newly ed Scottish Tory leader Ruth Davidson, a ready target to attack the Yes movement.In an urgent question at Holyrood, Labour MSP James Kelly asked Mr Mackay what impact a new currency would have on business.:SNP members support new currency as soon as practicableMr Mackay said: ldquoFirstly, our proposals are to keep the pound in the immediate term, and an SNP government will take steps necessary to enable the Scottish Parliament to authorise the preparation of a Scottish currency as soon as practicable after independence.ldquoThe Sustainable Growth Commission established by the First Minister in her capacity as SNP leader produced a detailed report on the financial, economic and regulatory requirements necessary for the transition to an independent currency.ldquoIt engaged extensively with businesses in developing its recommendations. It recommended the introduction of six tests to guide that transition, one of which is the financial requirements of Scottish residents and businesses.ldquoThose tests were back by SNP conference on Saturday. Our position is clear. Until a new currency can be safely and established in the interests of the whole economy, the currency of an independent Scotland should continue to be the pound sterling.Mr Kelly said the SNP wanted to drop the pound immediately, devaluing savings, and would make Scottish families and business ldquosignicantly worse off.Mr Mackay, who was on the Growth Commission, said he was ldquodelighted the currency resolution he co-authored was passed - after activists added ldquoas soon as practicable.He said: ldquoWe have set out, in terms of currency, the position that we continue with the pound. Wersquove set out the tests that will guide our decisions.ldquoIt will be for an independent Scottish Parliament when the time is right -there is that change - based on the right economic position for Scotland.ldquoAnd those tests - fiscal sustainability, central bank credibility, financial requirements of Scottish residents and business, sufficiency of foreign exchange and financial reserves, fit to trade and investment patterns, and correlation of economic and trade cycle - these are sensible tests that would guide such a decision.Tory MSP Murdo Fraser said: ldquoItrsquos only been three days since the vote at his conference and already the cabinet secretary is in full retreat from the position set out at that conference.He asked what work had been done on the ldquoextra transaction costs for Scots firms trading with the rest of the UK - Scotlandrsquos biggest export market - using a dferent currency.Mr Mackay said: ldquoWe will be keeping the pound on independence, and of course we can build our options as an independent country.ldquoWersquove set out the tests that we would apply to any potential change of currency.ldquoWersquove set out our preferred position. And wersquove also shown, really importantly, how our economic policies would be enhancedwe had the powers of independence.ldquoThat would grow our economy, deliver greater fairness and empower us to make the right decisions by the people of Scotland.In response to SNP MSP Bruce Crawford, Mr Mackay agreed the currency would remain the pound after a Yes vote and only change when an independent parliament decided that.ldquoOur policy is that we will support a change as soon as it can done safely and securely in the interests of the country, the economics of the country, when the time is right.Mr Mackayrsquos comments followed more criticism of the plan to ditch the pound.A former member of and an adviser to the partyrsquos Growth Commission both questioned the move, saying it could jeopardise peoplersquos savings and was not a priority.Richard Marsh, an external adviser to the Growth Commission, warned savers and householders could he hammeredthe new currency has less value than sterling.In , the Scottish Governmentrsquos own Fiscal Commission Working Group warned a new currency was a ldquosignicant undertaking in the short-term, though not unprecedented, and Scotland would need to ldquore-denominate all domestic wages, prices and contracts.Ms Sturgeonrsquos special advisers were unable to say at the weekend whether a new currency would be pegged to sterling - with the Scottish pound worth the same as a UK pound, for example - or float on the international money markets, and potentially be devalued.Mr Marsh said devaluation could wipe out yearsrsquo of savings and leave , householders trapped in negative equity, as their mortgages were recalculated in the new currency.He told the Scottish Daily Mail: ldquoThe Scottish Government may seek to absorb some of this risk to protect mortgage and asset values by pegging the currency.ldquoBut [given] this could be at the cost of public services and delivery, this would be a dficult decision for any new administration to make.ldquoIf Scotland took a lsquobig bangrsquo approach with a new currency set up shortly after a vote for independent, then it would mean businesses, iniduals and the Government would need to take account of movements in exchange rates between the newly established Scottish pound and sterling.Dan Macdonald, a former member of the Growth Commission, said currency was ldquoalmost irrelevant compared to economic growth and ldquosecondary in the independence debate.He said: ldquoWe need plans for the economy over the next five to ten years. That is more important than any one issue, including the constitutional question - we need to build the economy first.Financier Peter de Vink, a friend of Alex Salmond who backed Yes in , said a fledgling independent Scottish currency would be a magnet for speculators.The director of Edinburgh Financial and General Holdings said the result could be worse than Black Wednesday in , when speculators made millions betting on sterlingrsquos devluation, sending interest rates soaring.He said: ldquoThe pound was devalued by  per cent and that was in Britain - Scotland is a tenth of the size, so it would be even more of a problem. It would be devastating.ldquoIt is cloud cuckoo land stuffthey think they can do it. I thought there would be a little more brain power.ldquo[At] the last referendum, we avoided the currency issue as much as we could because we all knew it would be the most dficult thing.ldquoTalking about a currency is all wishful thinkingyou havenrsquot got a strong economy, and Scotland is not going to have a stronger economyScotland continues to have higher taxes than the rest of the United Kingdom.An SNP spokesperson said: "Scotland will keep the pound immediately after independence."The SNPs policy is to make a managed and responsible transition to an independent currency, only when it is safe, secure and practicable to do so."

title: tories-set-for-local-elections-drubbing-which-could-spell-beginning-of-end-for-theresa-mays-premiership
story: In some places turnout can be lower than  per cent.And while Brexit might have galvanised some to venture to the polling stations, equally it could be a big turn-off to others.While there are no council elections in Scotland and Wales or London this time round, the political focus will, at the end of this week, be on England and just how big a drubbing Theresa Mayrsquos party will receive at the hands of disgruntled voters.Most of the seats up for grabs on Thursday were fought over on the day of the  General Election when David Cameron won an unexpected Commons majority albeit of just . So the Tories start this weekrsquos contest from a high water-mark.It has been estimated the Conservatives, defending the largest number of seats, more than ,, could lose some  or  per cent.Politically, this will be bad for the Prime Minister, continuing to wrestle in a Brexit straitjacket, and yet another drubbing in the European elections, still scheduled for May , could spell the end for Mrs May.Altogether there are contests across  councils south of the border as well as  in Northern Ireland. Plus, there are elections for six directly elected mayors in the Midlands and northern England.More than half of the local councils, , are controlled by the Conservatives,  by Labour and seven by the Liberal Democrats. Some  have no overall control. The remaining five are new councils because of local authority mergers.While the Conservatives are just one seat away from winning Scarborough and could win the Midlands authorities of Walsall and Dudley, the elections are set to see big gains for Labour and the Lib Dems at the expense of the Tories.Labour has its sights on places like Trafford in Greater Manchester and Redcar and Cleveland in the north east of England while the Lib Dems are looking to their traditional areas of North East Somerset and Bath as well as Winchester.Although the key local topics will be the Conservative mantra of how Tory councils provide better services for less money and Labourrsquos pledge to improve bus services, the pervading Remain or Leave arguments of Brexit are set to dominate.Boris Johnson, one of the expected candidates to challenge for the Conservative crown once Mrs May steps aside, has made a last-ditch plea to voters not to take out their Brexit ldquofrustrations on effective and hard-working Tory councillors.Fellow Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg made a similar appeal earlier this week, saying: ldquoPeople, I hope, will think as they go to the polling station, that this is about their council tax, about their bin collection, about their road maintenance. Its not about Brexit.He added: ldquoIt would be very sadsome very good councillors lost because of a Brexit-related muddle."However, such a sentiment could fall on deaf ears as voters direct their anger largely at the incumbent government, which has failed to get Brexit over the line despite all the promises to do so.Around half the votes will be counted overnight on Thursday with the results due in the early hours of Friday morning while the other half will be counted Friday morning with the results due by lunchtime.Once they are in, the writing could be on the wall for Mrs Mayrsquos premiership.

Vote for Change UK."In other developments:*a poll ahead of the Euro elections placed the Tories fourth in London on just  points behind Labour on , Nigel Faragersquos Brexit Party on  and Change UK on .:Theresa May mindful of public mood and wants to wrap up cross-party talks next week*Mrs May faces a fresh challenge to her leadership after Tory grassroots chiefs forced an emergency summit in June on whether to demand she should step down.*Pro-EU Best for Britain launched a national campaign to encourage . million people, including , in Scotland, who are eligible to vote in the upcoming EU elections to do so by the May  deadline after its commissioned research showed they were not registered on the electoral roll.*Labour said uncertainty over Brexit was causing the UK to have the highest levels of stockpiling "of any G country ever" and damaging cash flow in the manufacturing sector.

title: herald-diary-a-meeting-of-staggies-and-canaries
story: IT is reported that former Prime Minister Tony Blair has suggested merging the English and Scottish football leagues in order to keep the Union alive. Not everyone is convinced by the idea. As James Doleman puts it: "Scotland would be independent by the end of the first season." And as another football fan put it: "Ross County versus Norwich  Have you ever thought of driving from Dingwall to Norwich  Ive done it ndash and its not fun."Follow followNOW that was a sore one. Thank you." Rangers fan and retired cop James replied: "Four thousand people voting ndash thatrsquos not many is it Mr Yousaf " to which Humza simply replied after having a look at Jamess Twitter account: "Its  more than the number of followers you have..."Flight frightA SECURITY scare on board an easyJet flight to Glasgow yesterday reminded us of an excitable tabloid newspaper headlining "The Ugly Truth" when model Kate Moss caused a disturbance on an easyJet flight by swigging duty-free vodka from her cabin baggage on board and having a sweary altercation with a fellow passenger. title: family fun at aberdeenshire wellbeing festival
story: As part of the Aberdeenshire Wellbeing Festival, Live Le Aberdeenshire will be running free cultural and sports events across the region, with over , opportunities for people to get involved.Highlights include three Best Medicine Comedy Nights in Macduff, Inverurie and Stonehaven in partnership with Breakneck Comedy and the Alcohol and Drugs Partnership, and an animation workshop delivered by Andy Symanowski, director and animator of Aardman Animations’ ‘Shaun the Sheep’ series.Live Le Aberdeenshire, a business unit of Aberdeenshire Council, is also working with Luminate, Scotland’s Older People’s Festival, and CityMoves Dance Agency in Aberdeen, to present Chance to Dance, a whole day of movement workshops for those aged over . Taster sessions in creative writing, painting, pottery and i-Movie making will also be available alongside opportunities such Playlist for Le events for people living with dementia.There are also mindfulness sessions led by guru Martin Stepek, Makaton demonstrations by the NHS speech and language therapists, and ‘Boogie in the Library’.Fire Scotland will be delivering CPR demonstrations in ious libraries with manikins available for participants to practice their le saving skills under the supervision of experts.The Aberdeenshire Wellbeing Festival supports Mental Health Awareness Week which runs from Monday, May  to Sunday, May  and is run through partnership organisations including Live Le Aberdeenshire and NHS Grampian.With  accessible activities for all ages, abilities and interests, across more than  venues, there’s something for everyone.David Cook, Aberdeenshire Culture  Sports Sub-Committee Chair said: “We’re delighted to support the Wellbeing Festival this year, and provide events that are inclusive, welcoming and free to take part in. The team has worked hard to secure national and local funding to boost the range of activities on offer.”Aberdeenshire Council’s Communities Committee Chair Cllr Anne Stirling added: “The promotion of positive health and well-being is a key aim for Live Le Aberdeenshire. It’s great to see such a range of activities that offer plenty of opportunity to spend quality ‘me time’ as well as enjoy fun cultural activities with friends and family.” Look out for the Wellbeing Festival brochure in libraries, and community, health and leisure centres around Aberdeenshire.Full event listings are also available here and at www.liveleaberdeenshire.org.uk and also lists other activities in the Live Le Aberdeenshire Performance and Events Programme.The Aberdeenshire Wellbeing Festival supports Mental Health Awareness Week which runs from  to  May.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The  champion from Kinclune"  Thainstone prepares for annual show and saleviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Police Scotland"  Vandals strike at Inverurie school viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

story: The Inverurie Business Associationheld their inaugural Business Expo as part of its Annual General Meeting last week.The meeting was held on Thursday, April  at the Fly Cup Café to an audience from the local business community, councillors and other interested parties from the wider Inverurie area.The Business Expo attracted a range of local businesses to promote their products and services to the IBA AGM attendees. title: new recycling procedures rolled out across aberdeenshire
story: New procedures are being rolled out across Aberdeenshire Council#s kerbside collection service from this week in an attempt to reduce the contamination of recycling bins with non-recyclable items.The aim is to reduce the amount of recyclates which can’t be processed because they’ve been mixed with non-recyclable materials, helping to avoid sending items to landfill and reducing disposal costs. The council’s Infrastructure Services Committeeapproved the kerbside collection policy and procedures last year, including guidance on how to deal with contaminated bins. Any non-recyclable material placed into the recycling bin is classed as ‘contamination’, which could spoil the recyclates in any load. The recycling reprocessor may then reject whole loads as a result. Any rejected loads of recycling are disposed of at an additional cost to the taxpayer, for which there is no council budget available. Income which they would have generated to invest in services is lost.Collection crews will now visually check each recycling bin for contaminated recycling before emptying as a matter of course – those with severe contamination will not be emptied. Households consistently presenting severely contaminated bins will be offered advice and support to properly separate their waste. Those who ignore that advice could run the risk of their recycling bin being removed.Moderately contaminated bins will be emptied and an orange tag will be attached, providing information to the householder on how to properly use the recycling service. If a bin has not been emptied and tagged explaining why it has not been emptied, it is contaminated and the offending materials must be removed before the next collection. Crews will notto empty a rejected bin until the next scheduled collection day for the same bin.Bins considered to have little or no levels of contaminants will be emptied as normal.Collection crews will keep a record of bins unemptied due to overloading or contamination and this will be checked before a decision is made toto empty any bin reported as a missed collection.For those with a lot of recyclable materials, additional, free recycling bins can be requested by contacting the council’s Wasteline. Additional non-recyclable waste bins may also be authorised where there is a genuine need following a home visit and assessment by a Community Waste Officer. data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.buchanobserver webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Police Scotland"  Police urge revellers to be safe and responsible viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BUCH | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BUCH | Article Teaser"The council’s Head of Roads, Waste and Landscape services, Philip McKay, said: “It’s important residents understand how to recycle properly and make best use of the facilities available to them. “Sending waste to landfill costs more than double the amount it costs to recycle and tackling the levels of contamination in kerbside bins is intended to reduce the amount of recyclates sent to landfill.“We will be enforcing the procedures in a staggered rollout, tackling problem routes first. This will allow crews to get used to the new procedures without any severe implications for the collection schedule.”Over half the materials in local non-recyclable waste bins are recyclable through existing services – equating to around , tonnes of recyclable materials being landfilled at a cost of £.million a year.Not only does maximising the value of a material benefit the environment, it also frees up money for other essential council services.Residents are encouraged to get in touch with the Recycling and Waste Aberdeenshire Facebook pagethey are unsure of how to dispose of any material not listed in the A-Z guide.For any recycling and waste related queries, or to request an additional recycling or non-recycling bin, please contact Wasteline.

title: occasional hours licence for brewdog
story: An Aberdeenshire licensing authority has narrowly paved the way for the anticipated opening of BrewDog#s new #, Inverurie bar and restaurant next month.Despite the brewing giants not possessing a provisional licence, Aberdeenshire Central Licensing Board took the highly unusual step of granting two occasional licences to enable it to open in the former Mitchell’s Dairy premises on Market Street.Some  new staff can now be employed at the bar which will see the number of BrewDog employees in Aberdeenshire soar to more than .BrewDog retail director James Brown told the board the firm had made “a huge commitment to Inverurie and Aberdeenshire” and afterwards said he was “delighted” with the decision which will initially allow the bar to operate from May  to .The company’s full licence application is currently being fast-tracked by the council after delays incurred due to the installation of a new data system and subsequent backlog.Under the agreement after a close - vote by licensing board members, the bar has been limited to operating from am to  midnight Sunday to Thursday and from am to am Friday and Saturday but only while former BrewDog Tap Room manager Craig Cargill is on the premises. Off-sales have been approved from am to pm Monday to Sunday.However, among ious conditions imposed by the licensing standards team, it was also agreed that the outdoor space to the rear of the premises will not be utilised by customers until a full licence is granted.The licensing board heard from Audrey Junner of agents Hill Brown Licensing that BrewDog had no intention to trade by way of occasional licences for an extended period of time.She added: “We would like to reassure members that a provisional premises licence has been submitted… for the avoidance of doubt my clients wholly accept that no assumptions can be made about the grant of that provisional licence.“They have undertaken the fit-out works at the business entirely at their own risk.”But licensing standards officer Lisa Gordini reminded the board that while a provisional licence had been applied for, it would not be discussed until the board’s June meeting and could receive representations or objections which could impact on BrewDog’s operation.She maintained there was an argument that the board should not be granting any occasional licences which may “conflict with the consultation process” of the provisional licence application.After considerable debate, board member Robbie Withey proposed refusal of the application, saying the authority expected a six-month consultation period to process applications and that the company – which operates  bars around the world – should have applied sooner.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: anzac day respects paid in orkney 2
story: Those who lost their lives during wartime from Australia and New Zealand have been remembered in a service here in Orkney today, Anzac Day, the national day of remembrance in both those countries.In World War One, a campaign was launched on the Gallipoli Peninsula aimed at the capture of the Dardanelles, and so securing the free passage of shipping to the Black Sea.The campaign was launched on April , , and troops from both Australia and New Zealand were at the forefront of the attack, and they suffered heavy casualties.To mark the occasion in Orkney, a contingent from the Kirkwall branch of the Royal British Legion led the remembrance ceremony, at the four Anzac war graves at St Olaf’s Cemetery, which was also attended by members of the Stromness branch of the Royal British Legion, and members of the Orkney branch of the Royal Naval Association.Kirkwall Legion president Eddy Ross carried out a service of remembrance at the graveside.Australian Orkney resident Suzanne Carter was asked to lay a wreath to mark the occasion. Also among those present was Janine Miller, we of Australian national Greg Miller who also lives in Orkney.This year the wreath was laid on the final resting place of –year–old Royal New Zealand Navy Volunteer Reserve pilot, LieutenantThomas Noel Bush, who was tragically killed on December , .Lt Bush’s Hawker Sea Hurricane fighter plunged from the sky above Kirkwall straight into the Peedie Sea — while, only yards away, people were in their homes, or going about their daily business.On that fateful day, Lt Bush arrived to pick up the aircraft and, following a few pre-flight checks, took to the air.However, within minutes witnesses heard the aircraft`s engine revving at high speed and, from a height of approximately ft, it ed straight down into the Peedie Sea, killing the pilot instantly.Local emergency services and personnel from HMS Sparrowhawk were quickly on the scene, but nothing could be done for the unfortunate pilot.Lt Bush’s body was recovered from the wreckage and he was buried, with full military honours, in St Olaf`s Cemetery, on the outskirts of Kirkwall, on December , .Kirkwall branch of the Royal British Legion chairman Dougie Manson said: “Those who died came from far and wide to serve their countries overseas, coming here today is the least we can do to remember them. It is important that we mark the sacrice they made.” vw, px"  copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: businesses invited to young workforce event

story: newsEuropean Parliamentary Elections — Postal Vote ReminderApril ,  at : pm vw, px"  Voters wishing to get a postal vote for the forthcoming European Parliamentary Elections are being reminded that they need to apply by pm on May .To apply, contact the Electoral Registration Office on  or drop into their offices on , Broad Street, Kirkwall or by emailing ero@orkney.gov.ukPacks will be sent out from May  onwards and will contain three items — a ballot paper, aenvelope and a postal voting statement attached to a ballot paper envelope.Postal votes should be posted to reach the Council Offices no later than pm on May , polling day. However, postal votes can also be handed into polling stations and the Council Offices at School Place on the day of the election before pm.Around  per cent of Orkney#s electorate has a postal vote, meaning that they do not have to attend a polling station on polling day to vote.At this point in time, the UK will be holding elections to the European Parliament on Thursday, May  and arrangements have been put in place by Orkney Islands Council’s elections team, in line with local authorities across the country.Electors under the age of  will not be eligible to vote in this election.EU citizens living in Orkney are being contacted about additional paperwork they will need to completethey intend to vote in the county. title: ev charging fees set for to be introduced in may
story: Fees for using Orkney Islands Council’s electric vehicle chargers are set to be introduced next month.The move follows a public consultation in December last year and discussion with the Orkney EV Owners’ Group.OIC currently provides four rapid and  fast-medium chargers that are free-to-use at present.Charges will be brought in from Monday, May :Darren Richardson, the council’s head of infrastructure and strategic projects, said: “Our community is leading the way when it comes to EV uptake.“There are more than  EVs in Orkney – a higher percentage of vehicles on our roads are powered by electricity than anywhere  in Scotland.“Our network of chargers plays an important role in supporting this and we’re currently installing more chargers at a range of locations.“But the cost of providing this service increases as more and more drivers make the switch to EV ownership and make use of the chargers — and we’ve reached the point where we need to introduce fees for their use.”He added: “We believe many EV owners will support us in this and, more widely, the public have indicated a willingness to see new charges brought in for some of the services the council provides,this helps prevent cuts to frontline services.“Introducing fees for use of our EV chargers will assist with the running costs, including routine and reactive maintenance and electricity consumption.“We’ve worked with the local EV owners’ group in developing this set of charges and will trial these over the next  months. We will monitor what effect they have on use of our EV chargers and this will help us review the fees we set in future.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: ferry walkway repair could take months say oic
story: The passenger walkway used by foot passengers using the mv Hamnavoe could be out of action for months.The walkway at Stromness Ferry Terminal has suffered signicant damage, following a hydraulic system failure, meaning passengers have been boarding and disembarking the ferry through its car ramps.Orkney Islands Council owns and operates the walkway and the council says that the repair bill could be “substantial”.“It is important to find out what caused this — and this is being looked at, as is a full assessment of the repairs that will be needed,” Councillor Graham Sinclair said.“Repair work has started. But, given the damage, it’s going to take some time before the walkway is operational again.“Until we know the full extent of the work required, it’s dficult to say with certainty how long it will be out of action, but it could be a number of months.“We realise this will cause inconvenience for passengers and for NorthLink Ferries. title: kirkwall streets to reopen this week
story: Orkney Islands Council have confirmed that street closures in the centre of Kirkwall are due to come to an end, this week, as the first stage of the Places and Spaces project reaches completion.Broad Street, Castle Street and Albert Street have been closed to vehicles whilst major street works were carried out. With new surfacing laid over the last week, the council say that a short time will be required for the surface to cure, with the streets to reopen to traffic on Friday at the latest.The works are part of the Kirkwall Townscape Heritage Initiative’sPlaces and Spaces project, which include changes to the area at the bottom of the Strynd and top of Castle Street, as well as providing a new path to the War Memorial on the Kirk Green.With the initial phase of the project now completed, works will be suspended for the main summer season. Plans are for work to move to the entrance to Victoria Street in the autumn, being suspended again in December for Christmas shopping season.The Places and Spaces initiative was developed alongside community groups such as the Kirkwall and St Ola Community Council and the Kirkwall BID, who identied key areas of the town where it was felt improvements could be made. According to OIC, proposed improvements were the positively received by the Orkney community during a two-day consultation period, where  per cent of those who attended said they supported the proposals,  per cent were against and the rest were undecided.The Kirkwall Townscape Heritage Initiative is a five-year heritage-based grant scheme which seeks to deliver sustainable improvements to the built heritage of the Kirkwall Conservation Area, in an effort to regenerate the centre of Kirkwall for the benefit of local communities and businesses, as well as to attract visitors. The scheme has been running since July  and will conclude in June.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: northlink takes the lead on reducing waste
story: Plastic items — including glasses, cups, lids, teaspoons and portion pots — have either been removed or replaced with sustainable alternatives. Ethical beverage supplier Ethyco now supplies  per cent compostable single-use cups and lids across NorthLink Ferries’ food and drink outlets.Ceramic catering pots have also replaced plastic pots and reusable polycarbonate beakers have replaced wax-lined disposable drinking cups. The replacement beakers have led to approximately , disposable cups and , plastic lids being removed from the waste stream per annum.More than , polystyrene food trays used in children#s meal packages have been replaced by a plant-based and  per cent compostable alternative.Seumas Campbell, Serco’s customer service director for NorthLink Ferries, said: “Looking after the natural environment is such an important part of the service we provide. So we are passionate about minimising our impact on the world around us. The steps we have taken to remove single-use plastics are very positive and we will keep looking for more opportunities to reduce our environmental footprint.”One Stop Waste Solutions, an Aberdeen-based recycling and waste services company, has seconded that NorthLink Ferries has already met the criteria for the  ban on general commercial waste sent to landfill.Craig Donoghue, managing director of the organisation added: “We have been working closely with NorthLink Ferries since , and in that time have seen a sustained effort to recycle and reduce waste. In particular, this commitment has peaked since  coinciding with ‘the Attenborough effect’. The company’s ongoing commitment will continue to lead the way in the journey towards zero waste.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
